facts.text: Defendants 1 to 6 were members of an undivided Hindu family known as Kalakkad Pannayar family in Tirunelveli District.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 1 to 6 are the debtors. They were members of an undivided Hindu family known as Kalakkad Pannayar family in Tirunelveli District. The family was doing Commission agency business in petrol, kerosene and crude oil.

facts.text: The family became heavily indebted by about June, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The members of the family became heavily indebted by about June, 1936, and as a result there was a pressure from their creditors.

facts.text: A deed of composition was executed Ex. B. 2 on July 8, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: In order to meet the said pressure a deed of companyposition was executed  EX. B. 2  on July 8, 1936.

facts.text: 56 out of the creditors agreed to a scheme for settlement of their debts under the deed.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this companyposition 56 out of the creditors of the family agreed to a scheme for settlement of their debts.

facts.text: Defendant 7 was constituted as a trustee under the deed of composition.

anchor.surface_text: Under this deed defendant 7 was companystituted as a trustee and as such was empowered to take over the assets of the debtors,

facts.text: Ayyah Ayyar filed an insolvency petition No. 26 of 1936 on July 30, 1936 in Sub-Court Tirunelveli against defendants 1 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the scheme under the companypetition companyld be successfully or effectively worked out one of the creditors, Ayyah Ayyar, filed an insolvency petition, No. 26 of 1936,

facts.text: Defendants 1 to 6 executed a deed of trust Ex.B.7 on August 26, 1936 conveying all movable and immovable properties to three trustees: defendant 7 Subbarayalu Reddiar, Veerabahu Pillai and Narayana Pillai.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of these a proceedings, on August 26, 1936 defendants 1 to  ff executed a deed of trust,  Ex.B.7  by this document they companyveyed all their movable and immovable properties

facts.text: Narayana Pillai died in February, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Narayana Pillai died in February, 1938. Veerabahu Pillai died some time before the present suit was instituted.

facts.text: Trustees took possession of immovable properties, paid secured creditors, arranged 50% payment to unsecured by selling properties.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees accerted the trust and entered upon their duties. They took possession of the immovable properties companyered by the trust.

facts.text: All immovable properties except family house conveyed under trust deed.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that except their family house in which defendants 1 to 6 resided all other immovable properties belonging to them were companyveyed under the trust deed.

facts.text: Defendant 14 had mortgage Ex. B-95 for Rs. 30,000 on June 3, 1935 at 10% compound interest.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant 14 was a secured creditor in whose favour a mortgage of the first schedule properties had been excelled for a sum of Rs. 30,000 on June 3, 1935  Ex. B- 95 . This mortgage carried 10, companypound interest.

facts.text: Trustees conveyed Schedule I properties to defendant 14 for Rs. 42,000 on May 22, 1937 Ex. B94 by two trustees.

anchor.surface_text: In order to pay off the debts thus due to defendant 14 the trustees companyveyed to him schedule I mortgaged properties for Rs. 42,000 on May 22, 1937  EX. B 94

facts.text: Defendants 1 to 6 brought suit O.S. No. 30 of 1943 in Sub Court Tirunelveli for administration of trust.

anchor.surface_text: In 1943 defendants 1 to 6 brought a suit, o. s. . No. 30 of 1943 in the Sub Court at Tirunelveli for the administration of the trust created by them,

facts.text: Present suit filed on October 29, 1947 by three plaintiffs creditors on behalf of general body under O.1 R.8.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst the proceedings in the said three appeals were pending in the High Court and before defendants 1 to 6 were allowed to withdraw the litigation the present suit was filed on October 29, 1947,

facts.text: Trial court passed decree declaring properties in schedules I to III, V, VII, VIIA, VIII impressed with trust, removed def7, appointed administrators, ordered delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: In substance the trial judge rejected the plaintiffs claim for account, but he passed a decree declaring that the properties described ill schedules I to III, V, VII, I to and VIII companytinued to be impressed with the trust

facts.text: Madras High Court confirmed trial court decree subject to modification on interest by judgment dated March 25, 1953 in A.S. Nos. 731 and 720 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated March 25, 1953, of the Madras High Court in A. S. Nos. 731 and 720 of 1950.

facts.text: Courts below found alienations to defendant 14 (Ex B-94) and defendant 13 (Ex B-37) invalid as executed by only two out of three trustees.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been found that Exs. B-94 and B-37 are invalid for the reason that they have bee executed by only two out of the three trustees,

facts.text: Courts found transfers to defendants 12,13,16 invalid as to relations of trustee Veerabahu Pillai.

anchor.surface_text: whereas the transfers under EXS. B-12, B-13 and be 16 held to be invalid as they are transfers in favour of the relations of one of the trustees Veerabahu.

facts.text: Defendant 12 found to be trustee de son tort by intermeddling with trust estate.

anchor.surface_text: It has further been found that defendant 12 intermeddled with the estate of the trust and must therefore be regarded as trustee de son tort

facts.text: Both courts rejected pleas of res judicata and limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Courts have rejected the plea of res judicata and limitation raised by the defendants.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed Civil Appeal No. 62 of 1959 by defendants 14 and 18-24.

anchor.surface_text: In the result Civil Appeal No. 62 of 1959 files by defendants 14 and 18 to 24 fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Clause 23 of trust deed requires all three trustees to act unanimously or by majority decision.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 23 has been thus translated by the High Court In all the proceedings to be taken in companynection with this estate, you three, either unanimously or according to the decision of the majority, shall act.

facts.text: Narayana Pillai did not consent to sale Ex. B-94.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this question the trial companyrt has referred to the discrepant versions given for Narayana Pillai number joining in the execution of the sale deed.

facts.text: All impugned alienations found for inadequate consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated both the Courts below have found that all these alienations were effected for inadequate companysideration.

holdings.text: The present suit does not attract Article 120 of the Limitation Act and is not barred by limitation; it is a claim for possession attracting Articles 131 or 134.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the argument that the prayer made in the plaint attracts Art. 120 must be rejected. The next contention urged is that the plaintiffs cannot sue for possession but must Confine themselves only to a claim for declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint claims declaration plus appointment of administrator for possession; valued under s.7(v) Court Fees Act for possession; joins persons in possession as necessary parties.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs as beneficiaries under private trust can sue for possession of trust properties via appointment of new trustee/administrator; s.63 Trusts Act not exhaustive.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention urged is that the plaintiffs cannot sue for possession but must Confine themselves only to a claim for declaration. It is not disputed by the learned Attorney-General that in regard to public charitable trusts

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.63 provides remedies but not exhaustive; precedents for charitable trusts apply analogously; policy avoids anomalous results like two suits leading to adverse possession; s.10 implies following property.

holdings.text: Present suit not barred by res judicata from dismissal of O.S. No. 30/1943.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question of res judicata. The argument is that on general grounds of res judicata the dismissal of the suit O. S. No. 30 of 1943 filed by defendants 1 to 6 should preclude the trial of the present suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.11 CPC inapplicable due to different parties (representative suit by creditors vs. debtors); no general res judicata outside s.11 for suits.

holdings.text: Sale deeds executed by only two out of three trustees (Exs. B-94, B-37) invalid as all must join under s.48 Trusts Act; cl.23 requires all three to act even on majority decision, no exception.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.48 mandates all trustees join unless deed otherwise provides; cl.23 translation requires 'you three' to act unanimously or by majority, meaning all participate in action; conforms to s.48.

holdings.text: High Court had jurisdiction to amend decretal order under ss.151/152 CPC to correct clerical error (mesne profits to net profits) even after Supreme Court admission of appeals.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clerical error in decree inconsistent with judgment; ss.151/152 allow correction anytime.

holdings.text: Alienees liable for net profits from date of possession beyond 3 years under Art.109 as part of equitable adjustment with interest granted to them.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Equitable adjustment between trust (profits) and alienees (principal+interest); Art.109 not bar in integrated decree; precedents support.

holdings.text: Defendant 14 entitled to simple interest at 10.5% not compound under original mortgage in equitable adjustment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree not mortgage suit revival but equitable recognition of dues; simple interest suffices justice.

holdings.text: Defendant 12 intermeddled with trust estate over years (letters, compromise, receipts) and is trustee de son tort; sale Ex.B-90 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We will take the case of defendant 12 first. We have already seen that in favour of defendant 12 a sale deed has been executed on November 7, 1941 Ex. B-90 . This sale deed has been set aside on two grounds- one that it is executed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of directions to clerk, negotiations with bank, compromises as non-creditor show intermeddling; concurrent findings upheld.

holdings.text: Transfers to relatives of trustee (defendants 12,13,16: step-brothers, son-in-law) invalid under s.52 Trusts Act prohibiting trustee/agent/ indirect purchase.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.52 bars trustee, agent, third person indirectly; relatives covered per Lewin; no delegation under s.47.

holdings.text: All impugned alienations effected for grossly inadequate consideration; concurrent findings upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated both the Courts below have found that all these alienations were effected for inadequate consideration. It has also been found that Exs. B-94 and B-37 are invalid for the reason that they have been executed by only two out of the three trustees

holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts valued properties based on evidence (double/single crop distinguished); plaintiffs' evidence unrebutted; no interference with concurrent findings.

holdings.text: Narayana Pillai did not consent or approve sales Exs.B-94, B-37; concurrent findings.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this question the trial court has referred to the discrepant versions given for Narayana Pillai not joining in the execution of the sale deed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discrepant defendant evidence; low prices; no minutes; preferred debtor evidence.

holdings.text: Civil Appeal No. 62 of 1959 by defendants 14 and 18-24 dismissed with costs; Civil Appeal No. 77 of 1959 by defendants 12,13,16 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result Civil Appeal No. 62 of 1959 filed by defendants 14 and 18 to 24 fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All substantial issues rejected; decree confirmed subject to interest modification.

precedents.citation: A. Subramania Iyer v. P Nagarathna Naicker  1

anchor.surface_text: A. Subramania Iyer v. P Nagarathna Naicker  1 , it was held by the Madras High Court that in a suit by the worshippers of a temple to have the alienation of the trust property by some of the defendants, trustees. to the other defendants declared invalid and for possession to the trustees, the proper decree to be made if the Court be of the opinion that the alienation is invalid is to decree possession to those defendants who are trustee.

precedents.case_name: A Subramania Iyer v P Nagarathna Naicker
precedents.cited_proposition: In a suit by worshippers of a temple to set aside alienation of trust property by trustees and for possession to trustees, the decree should be for possession to the trustees without referring to a separate suit.
precedents.cited_holding: the proper decree to be made if the Court be of the opinion that the alienation is invalid is to decree possession to those defendants who are trustee. It was further held that the trustees need number be referred to a separate suit for the purpose.

precedents.citation: masjid Shahid Ganj v. Shiromani, gurdwara Parbandhak Committee, Amritsar  2

anchor.surface_text: masjid Shahid Ganj v. Shiromani, gurdwara Parbandhak Committee, Amritsar  2  the Privy Council has recognised this right in these words The right of a Muslim worshipper may be regarded as an individual right, but what is the nature of the right It is number a sort of easement in gross, but an element in the general right of a beneficiary to have the waqf property recovered by its proper custodians and applied to its proper purpose.

precedents.case_name: Masjid Shahid Ganj v Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee Amritsar
precedents.cited_proposition: Beneficiary has right to procure ejectment of trespasser and delivery of property to proper custodian like Mutawali.
precedents.cited_holding: The right of a Muslim worshipper may be regarded as an individual right... Such an individual may, if he sues in time, procure the ejectment of a trespasser and have the property delivered into the possession of the Mutawali or of some other person for the purposes of the waqf.

precedents.citation: Rani  Chhatra Kumari Devi v. Prince Mohan Bikram Shah  1

anchor.surface_text: Rani  Chhatra Kumari Devi v. Prince Mohan Bikram Shah  1 . In that case the respondent had claimed title to the properties as owner in various ways and had sued as the proprietor of the properties companyered by the action. All these grounds were rejected and it was held that the respondent companyld claim numbertitle as a proprietor at all.

precedents.case_name: Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi v Prince Mohan Bikram Shah
precedents.cited_proposition: Beneficiary under private trust cannot sue for possession as owner; limited to declaration; Indian law does not recognize legal/equitable estates separately.
precedents.cited_holding: their Lordships were unable to hold that this would entitle him to sue for possession as owner... the right of a beneficiary is, in proper case, to call upon the trustee to Convey to him... barred after six years under Art. 120

precedents.citation: Subbaiya Pandaram v. Mahamad Mustapha Maracayar  1

anchor.surface_text: Subbaiya Pandaram v. Mahamad Mustapha Maracayar  1 , this is exactly what happened. In, the presence of the purchaser it was declared that the trust have been validly created and that the property was in fact a trust property. Their Lordships pointed out that at the moment when the said decree was passed the possession of the property was adverse

precedents.case_name: Subbaiya Pandaram v Mahamad Mustapha Maracayar
precedents.cited_proposition: Declaration that property is subject to trust does not disturb or affect the adverse possession of the alienee.
precedents.cited_holding: the declaration that the property had been properly made subject to the trust disposition... did number disturb or affect the quality of his possession it merely emphasised the fact that it was adverse.

precedents.citation: Lala Man Mohan Das v. Janki Prasad  1

anchor.surface_text: Lala Man Mohan Das v. Janki Prasad  1 . In support of the validity of these transfers an alternative argument has been urged before US. It is pointed out that according to Lewin on Trusts, if the act to the two trustees has been done with the sanction and approval of the third trustee then it may be regarded as an act of the three trustees,

precedents.case_name: Lala Man Mohan Das v Janki Prasad
precedents.cited_proposition: Sales executed by only two out of three trustees are invalid and pass no title.

precedents.citation: Satgur Prasad v. Har Narain Das  1

precedents.case_name: Satgur Prasad v Har Narain Das
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts can make equitable adjustments between parties in such cases.

precedents.citation: Bhagwat Dayal Singh v. Debi Dayal Sahu  2

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwat Dayal Singh v. Debi Dayal Sahu  2 . The principal and interest ordered to be paid to defendant 14 and the profits ordered to be paid by him are thus integral parts of on equitable adjustment between the plaintiffs and defendant 14.

precedents.case_name: Bhagwat Dayal Singh v Debi Dayal Sahu

precedents.citation: Jagnnath Prasad Singh Chowdhury Surajmal Jalal  a

anchor.surface_text: Jagnnath Prasad Singh Chowdhury Surajmal Jalal  a . In that case the Privy Council has held  1   1932  L. R. 59 1. A.A. 147.  2   1908  R. 35 I. A. 48, 59.  3   1926  L.R. 54 I. A. 1. that on a preliminary decree for foreclosure or sale under O. XXXIV ,rr. 2, 4 of the Code, a mortgagee is entitled to interest at the rate and with the . rests stipulated in the mortgage,

precedents.case_name: Jagannath Prasad Singh Chowdhury v Surajmal Jalal
precedents.cited_proposition: Mortgagee entitled to contract rate of interest in preliminary decree for foreclosure or sale.
precedents.cited_holding: a mortgagee is entitled to interest at the rate and with the rests stipulated in the mortgage, down to this date filed for redemption by the decree.

outcome.relief_summary: Civil Appeals Nos. 62 and 77 of 1959 fail and are dismissed; High Court decree upheld declaring alienations invalid, properties impressed with trust, trustee removed, administrator appointed, alienees directed to deliver possession and account for net profits
